render.tex: \title{Identity for an operation} \\ %text Identity for a binary operation and how to verify it %

reason.tex:
%text A few examples before moving to formal a definition % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{cccc} \hline \text{operation} & \text{on} & \text{Identity} & \text{example} \\ \hline + & \mathbb{R} & 0 & 7+0=7=0+7 \\ \times & \mathbb{R} & 1 & 15.12\times 1 = 15.12 = 1\times 15.12 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} \\ %text As the pattern suggests, the $identity$ $e$ is such an element, which if it exists for a binary operator $*:A\times A\rightarrow A$, will result in the following equation holding true,
%
\begin{align} a * e = a = e * a \end{align} \\
%text
Standard mathematical operators $-$ and $\div$ \underline\text{do not} have an identity operator due the their inherent asymmetry. Note: $*:A\times A\rightarrow A$ simple means an operation between two operands $\in$ $A$ whose result also $\in$ $A$. %
